custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: In 1987, the donor retrieved these materials from the office of Department of Drama and Dance professor Sherwood Collins, who had received these and other materials from the Balch family. Students and faculty were invited to take items of interest. These materials remained with the donor until 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Marston Balch Papers on World War II, 1928-1991. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing of this collection was completed by Leah Edelman in 2018. Materials were placed in archival folders and an archival box, and arranged by format. A file-level inventory and series-level description were created, and the finding aid was also created at the time of processing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains materials created or acquired by Department of Drama and Dance professor Marston Balch during or related to his service during World War II as part of the U.S. Information Service and the Cultural Relations Section of the U.S. State Department. Materials include photographs relating to the liberation of Paris in 1944, clippings and publications, correspondence, and souvenirs.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Marston Stevens Balch (1901-187), served in a variety of roles at Tufts University from 1934-1971 as professor of English, director of Drama, executive director of the Tufts College Theater, chair of the Department of Drama and Speech, and professor of Oratory for the Fletcher School. He resigned from the faculty of Arts and Sciences at Tufts University on May 3, 1971.

Marston Balch was born in Detroit, Michigan on November 21, 1901. In 1923 he received a degree in English from Kalamazoo College. Balch went on to attend Harvard for a Masters of Arts in 1925 and a Ph.D. in 1931, with both degrees in English with a concentration in dramatic literature and theater history.

He began his professional career in 1925 when he started serving as an instructor of English and the theatrical director at Williams College. He also taught in similar fields at Philips Exeter Academy from 1933 to 1934.

Balch joined Tufts in 1934 as an assistant professor of English. A year later, he also took on the roles of director of the Drama department, the executive director of the Tufts College Theater, and advisor to Tufts Pen, Paint and Pretzels, a student theatre group as well as the oldest student organization at Tufts . In 1940, under Balch's persuasion and effort, Tufts established the first Department of Drama and Speech in New England. From 1940 until 1966, he served as the chair of the Department of Drama and Speech, professor of Drama, and Professor of Oratory for the Fletcher School. He took leave from Tufts from 1943 â€“ 1946 to serve as chief of the French Press and Radio Analysis Section of the US Information Service, and as chief of Cultural Relations Section under the Department of State during World War II. Because of his service in World War II, he received multiple honors from France, including the Medaille de la Reconnaissance Francais (Medal of French Gratitude) in 1947 and Legion of Honor Medal from the French Government in 1953 . In 1960, he received the Distinguished Service Awards under in Tufts Alumni Awards Program. Marston Balch retired from Tufts in 1971.

Marston Balch married Germaine Cornier in September 1928. Germaine was a French native, and was a professor of French at Tufts University. They had a daughter, Gabrielle. Germaine Cornier passed away in 1969, and Balch was remarried to Roberta R. Blanchard in 1976. Balch died in 1987.

In 1983, the Marston S. Balch Arena Theatre, constructed as a part of the Aidekman Arts Center, was named in his honor upon the generous donation of one of his former students, Elizabeth Bottomley Noyce. The theater commemorates Balch's 37 years of service at Tufts and provides a unique space for drama productions in the round, a format pioneered by Balch himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains approximately 42 photographs relating to the liberation of Paris in August 1944.

did.langmaterial: Some materials in this file are in French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains clippings related to World War II from the New York Times and the New York Times Magazine, a color brochure titled "France" and published by the French government, a program of Radio France, a French newspaper from 1944, and leaflets dropped over Paris in 1945. This file also contains an undated publication titled "Young America Speaks" published by the Youth Committee of the English-speaking Union, a Congressional Record reprint of "The Spirit of France Still Lives" (1944), other miscellaneous clippings, and a 1991 issue of Prologue, published by the Tufts Department of Drama and Dance, with a biography of Marston Balch and details about the dedication of the Marston Balch Arena Theater in the Aidekman Arts Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains six anti-Nazi and anti-Germany stickers in English, French, and Arabic; eight postcards; a card from Bar Americain; and a letter from Marston Balch to his wife from 1945.
